paragraphs.paragraph: Geek is chic.

Yun Liang’s scroll cell phone drew inspiration from how traditional Chinese paintings are unfurled. It may be wildly untraditional given our current cell phone market (as in, it must be sleek and chic and have a touchscreen), but it offers a user experience far more unique and tactile than other concepts like the Rainbow gem phone. When you're not using it, the phone rolls into a neat little tube. All numeric key functions run along the side of the screen, which means it doesn't necessarily have to be unrolled to work. For an additional image, read more

When you're not using it, the phone rolls into a neat little tube. All numeric key functions run along the side of the screen, which means it doesn't necessarily have to be unrolled to work. For an additional image, read more

If you are constantly switching between purses, laptop bags, clutches, work bags, beach bags, handbags (you get the idea), then this purse organizer could be something you may find quite handy! Featured on Paperclippy, this organizer has lots of pockets for all your daily necessities, including your wallet, cell phone, iPod, keys, sunglasses, etc. Just roll it up, put it in your bag and transfer whenever needed. Priced at only $15. What do you think? Would this device make your life easier or is it unnecessary?
Love It or Leave It? Purse Organizer:
Love It
Leave It
Something else. See my comment below!

By now you probably know I'm totally addicted to my beautiful BlackBerry Pearl and my fabulous iPod. While they still hold the top spot of my favorite list, I am sure this will change when the iPhone arrives later this week! But what I want to know is, what are your favorite gadgets? Do you love Helly Kitty gadgets? Or maybe you have a thing for pink tech gear like this girl? Whether you are a Mac user, a PC type, a gamer, or a Zune junkie, I have created a special geeksugar group for the gadget lover in all of us called My Favorite Gadgets. It's a place where you can share all your amazing tech toys and geeky paraphernalia. And you just never know, your submission could possibly end up on the geeksugar homepage! To learn how to post photos of your favorite gadgets in the group, read more

Before I owned a digital camera I would take my 35mm film camera everywhere I went. One concern I always had was whether or not my film would be ruined going through airport security checkpoints. With traditional film cameras, there's a higher risk that film will be damaged by the X-Ray machines during security screening, even though this hasn't happened to me. Just to be on the safe side, have your camera checked separately by hand or ask the security staff if the X-Ray machines are safe for film - usually the posters in the area will indicate whether or not you need to remove film. As for digital cameras, your pictures should be completely safe.

Just to be on the safe side, have your camera checked separately by hand or ask the security staff if the X-Ray machines are safe for film - usually the posters in the area will indicate whether or not you need to remove film. As for digital cameras, your pictures should be completely safe.

paragraphs.paragraph: What was on the world's mind in 2011? Rebecca Black, according to Google's Zeitgeist 2011 roundup. The teen singer's viral video wonder "Friday" had over 167 million view on YouTube, and searches for her name made it the number one fastest-rising search term on the site in 2011.

Google's Zeitgeist review of the year is largely made up of the fastest-rising search terms in categories such as people, entertainment, consumer electronics, and news for every region worldwide. Interestingly, the fastest-falling searches are also listed with the once top social network, MySpace, securing the number one spot for losing the most global interest online this year.
Here's a detail of the fastest-moving US search terms in their respective categories:
For a closer look at the world's last 12 months through an Internet lens, get your tissues ready to watch Google's 2011 year in review video after the break.

Mark Zuckerberg introduced Timeline, which puts all of your activity in chronological order in a visually pleasing way, during the F8 conference earlier this year. Almost like a personal webpage for Facebook, this timeline beautifully shows off your large photos, status updates, and activity, but there's also a space for your favorite apps and a big profile photo up top. Privacy is top of mind on Timeline as well, as you're able to set the privacy access for every piece of content on your timeline. Take a quick look at each section of Timeline here.

Prime holiday shopping time is upon us. Do you have your list figured out? We've got gifts on the brain and have rounded up 168 gifts for all kinds of geeks in your life — from your nerdy co-worker to your best pal to your favorite Star Trek fanatic. Take a look through our list, check it twice, and tackle your shopping list early.

Please let the public-transit video-game handrails concept happen — Dvice Airline to let you use social networks to pick seatmates — Newser Six things movies get wrong about the workplace — Cracked Awesome Kinect hacks — Tecca Female superheroes are the spokeswomen for breast cancer awareness — GeekTyrant Sign us up for this panoramic ball camera! — SlashGear

Above all else, 2011 may be known in the tech world as the year we lost a visionary. Steve Jobs passed away in October after a long health battle, but his work will forever live on in our lives — whether its in current form, or ideas he left behind.

The lessons Steve Jobs learned from his time as founder to legendary CEO allowed him to truly live the life he loved — at home and at work. Here, a few notable quotes from Steve that will inspire you to live passionately, fully, and thankful, just as he did.
Source: Getty

headings.heading: Sugar Shout Out: Which Shirtless Guy Got Your Attention in 2011?
2011: The Year in Google
Facebook Timeline Goes Live Today
